body:
I wouldn't say awards were one of reddit's problems though. Here's the things we need to avoid:

* Censorship

* Power user cabals who collude with the admins, and admins playing favorites and keeping secrets with them

* Opaqueness

* Advertisers and the media pressuring the admins to delete things

* The post/comment sorting algorithm where even a single downvote early on will kill it forever.

* Being able to get banned so easily, and almost impossible for prominent members of the site who aren't friends with the admins to not get banned.

* Closing down +general as reddit did to /r/reddit.com and /r/profileposts
body_html:
I wouldn't say awards were one of reddit's problems though. Here's the things we need to avoid:

  • Censorship

  • Power user cabals who collude with the admins, and admins playing favorites and keeping secrets with them

  • Opaqueness

  • Advertisers and the media pressuring the admins to delete things

  • The post/comment sorting algorithm where even a single downvote early on will kill it forever.

  • Being able to get banned so easily, and almost impossible for prominent members of the site who aren't friends with the admins to not get banned.

  • Closing down +general as reddit did to /r/reddit.com and /r/profileposts

parent.body:
I'm admittedly ambivalent about the introduction of awards. It would be a good source of independent revenue for Ruqqus LLC, absolutely. But I'm also strongly concerned about our potential to become a parody of Reddit by too fully emulating their policies and practices.

On balance, I suppose I'm against it, but barely, and mostly because it would too strongly mimic Reddit.
parent.body_html:
I'm admittedly ambivalent about the introduction of awards. It would be a good source of independent revenue for Ruqqus LLC, absolutely. But I'm also strongly concerned about our potential to become a parody of Reddit by too fully emulating their policies and practices.

On balance, I suppose I'm against it, but barely, and mostly because it would too strongly mimic Reddit.

parent.body: Following up on this - I connected to Tor and logged into the account and it's now suspended. It was created in 2018 and never posted anything inflammatory or controversial and was never banned from any subs or had any comments removed. So it looks like they are doing/have done a historical sweep of any accounts created on and/or used with Tor.
parent.body_html: Following up on this - I connected to Tor and logged into the account and it's now suspended. It was created in 2018 and never posted anything inflammatory or controversial and was never banned from any subs or had any comments removed. So it looks like they are doing/have done a historical sweep of any accounts created on and/or used with Tor.

post.body: Any time you create an account using TOR now, it *will* be shadowbanned after a few days. And they will also scrub anything you posted prior to that, but won't put it in the subreddit's spam or modqueue so the mods won't even know to approve it. Test it out and see for yourself.
post.body_html: Any time you create an account using TOR now, it will be shadowbanned after a few days. And they will also scrub anything you posted prior to that, but won't put it in the subreddit's spam or modqueue so the mods won't even know to approve it. Test it out and see for yourself.
post.title: Reddit now shadowbans every single new account that uses TOR
